properties.title: The Associated Press: Health crisis in Haiti enters a deadly new phase
properties.description:
Diarrhea, Respiratory Illness &mdash; Haiti<br/>&ndash;
 1 day ago 
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti &#x2014; Fourteen-month-old Abigail Charlot survived Haiti's cataclysmic earthquake but not its miserable aftermath. Brought into the capital's General Hospital with fever and diarrhea, little Abigail literally dried up. 
"Sometimes they arrive too late," said Dr. Adrien Colimon, the chief of pediatrics, shaking her head. 
The second stage of Haiti's medical emergency has begun, with diarrheal illnesses, acute respiratory infections and malnutrition beginning to claim lives by the dozen.

properties.title: need water at hospital
properties.description:
Not Yet Classified &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Haiti<br/>Project Medishare for Haiti is working since the morning after the earthquake. It began with a 11 person trauma team and over the past weeks it has continued its massive coordination with over 5 flights transporting over 150 doctors, nurses and rescue workers not including excessive amounts of medical supplies already on site in Haiti along with facilities being consolidated for air cargo shipments. All efforts are being coordinated from Jackson Hospital through Dr. Green&acirc;s emergency execution team.

Our field hospital is set up at the airport and consists of 150 doctors and 170 to 250 patients. &Acirc;&nbsp;We are now consuming 1500 Liters of drinking water and 4000 Liters of tap water a day. &Acirc;&nbsp;For now we have exhausted our donation contacts and need help from your organization.

properties.description:

properties.title: 2010 Atlantic Hurricane Season Will Increase Infectious Disease Risk in Haiti
properties.description: Environmental &mdash; Haiti<br/>The onset of the 2010 Atlantic hurricane season on June 1st increases the risk of infectious disease activity among earthquake-affected populations in Haiti. A hurricane making landfall in Haiti will bring with it mass precipitation resulting in flooding and stagnant water collection. Saturation of grounds supporting temporary shelters for earthquake survivors will intensify already acute sanitation problems leading to increased exposure of persons to human and animal waste products. This presents an ideal trigger for increased diarrheal disease occurrence, in addition to water-borne illnesses including leptospirosis and typhoid. Similarly, flooding of grounds previously under drought conditions may increase the risk...

properties.title: Acute Respiratory Infections Main Cause of Morbidity
properties.description: Diarrhea, Respiratory Illness &mdash; Haiti<br/>According to an OCHA report published on February 11, Haitian Ministry of Health surveillance data indicates that acute respiratory infections are the main cause of morbidity [in Haiti]. The data was not further sub-categorized by age; it is our assessment diarrheal disease in children is likely underestimated by current surveillance data.

properties.title: Haiti Epidemic Advisory System (HEAS) SitRep: UPDATED 16 FEB
properties.description: Diarrhea, Respiratory Illness &mdash; Haiti<br/>Updated 0216 GMT, 16 FEB 2010 Disruptors Op Notes- Disruptors Surveillance Grid Status. Open dissemination of information from formal medical surveillance has not occurred to our knowledge and has been highlighted as a critical point of concern. Further, one major NGO on the ground in Haiti refused to share information regarding infectious disease events they were observing in children. It is our assessment this reflects current gaps in international agreements for what constitutes "critical information" considered mandatory to share openly with the humanitarian response community. This lack of broader information sharing and dissemination prevents realization of a fully efficient and...

properties.title: Gonaives, Saint-Marc, and Dessalines: Infectious Diseases Observed and General Observations
properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Haiti<br/>We interviewed a ground medical team consisting of missionaries and physicians who have a long history of working in Haiti; they returned a couple of days ago from the coastal areas north of PAP. Gonaive. This is the area where the team spent the greatest amount of time and direct observation. It is the third highest population density urban area in Haiti. In contrast to Saint-Marc, structural damage due to the earthquake was minimal. The biggest disruptors to their community were the floods of 2004 and 2008 and two recent crop failures, which they are still recovering from. They have...

properties.title: Haiti Epidemic Advisory System (HEAS) SitRep: UPDATED 20 FEB
properties.description: Diarrhea, Environmental &mdash; Haiti<br/>Updated 0510 GMT, 20 FEB 2010 Biosurveillance Grid Status. Two key issues have been identified with clarity now. Formal surveillance data is coordinated and authorized for release by the Haiti Ministry of Health (MOH). CDC and PAHO support the Haiti MOH in accordance with international agreements and thus must respect Haitian government's decision whether to release information. The second issue is independent of the political situation, where some major NGOs have refused to contribute to biosurveillance. The biosurveillance grid will remain suboptimal until information is shared openly and in a timely manner. Meteorology. See above for seasonal precipitation and temperature...

properties.title: Hyperendemic Transmission of Dengue and Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever Presentation in Haiti
properties.description: Dengue Fever, Hemorrhagic Fever &mdash; Haiti<br/>The risk of dengue infection in responders was discussed in some detail in a prior post. This post focuses on hyperendemic dengue transmission in the indigenous Haitian population. The attached study examined 210 children aged 6 to 13 from the Lekol Basil Moreau School, Bizoton, Carrefour Borough, Port-au-Prince, Haiti in June 1996. Dengue hemorrhagic fever is typically seen in indigenous children in endemic areas. Three pediatricians were interviewed from University of Haiti General Hospital in Port-au-Prince with continuous experience of up to 16 years. These physicians reported seeing no patients with symptoms consistent with dengue hemorrhagic fever. DEN-1, -2, and...

properties.title: Malaria Transmission in Haiti
properties.description: Malaria &mdash; Haiti<br/>Cholorquine-sensitive P. falciparum is the predominant strain (>90%) in Haiti and is transmitted primarily by the Anopheles albimanus mosquito. A. albimanus breeds in hoof and footprints, ditches, and rice fields. More than 80% of rice fields in Artibonite Valley sampled contained larvae in a survey by Caillouet, Keating, and Eisele in November 2006 (see attached): The minor rainy season begins in March, peaking in May. The major rainy season begins in August, peaking in October. Transmission of malaria is seasonal in Haiti, peaking typically in November: Transmission has been reported to be localized to certain villages and intense. A seroprevalance...

properties.title: Fort Royale: Measles and Mumps Reported by Rush Physicians
properties.description: Measles, Mumps &mdash; Haiti<br/>Although there has been no confirmed cases of measles or mumps reported through formal medical surveillance in Haiti, a physician from Rush University Medical Center deployed with International Medical Corps reported seeing one case of measles and a colleague who saw two cases of mumps in siblings.

properties.title: Typhoid Fatality Reported in IDP Camp in Port-au-Prince
properties.description: Typhoid &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Haiti<br/>A photojournalist reports a fatality due to typhoid in one of the PAP IDP camps. No report of increased cases.

properties.title: Flooding in Les Cayes
properties.description: Environmental &mdash; Les Cayes, Sud, Haiti<br/>Les Cayes, located in southwestern Haiti, did not experience damage from the earthquake as did Port-au-Prince. However, over this weekend 3,000 were evacuated to higher ground and 13 were killed due to heavy rainfall and flooding to a height of 5 feet. One hospital was forced to move 400 patients to higher floors because the ground floor was under water. As discussed in prior posts, flooding does occur before hurricane season as part of the normal minor rainy season in Haiti, which begins in March.

Formal medical surveillance is currently providing a partial picture of the ground situation. There have been problems with data collection such as reporter fatigue and consistency in reporting. properties.title: Medical Team Treating Patients in Delmas Reports Malaria and Diarrhea Cases
properties.description: Malaria, Diarrhea &mdash; Delmas, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Delmas, Ouest Department Disease Entity: Malaria, non-specified diarrheal disease Volunteers from a non-profit organization based in Florida returned to the United States from Haiti after a four-day deployment to provide treatment and medical supplies to earthquake survivors living in temporary shelter on a golf course in Delmas. It is reported that there are up to 40,000 individuals living in tents at this site. The medical team indicates they treated nearly 800 patients for diarrhea, as well as skin and parasitic infections. They also reported treating cases of malaria based on symptoms observed among patients.

properties.title: Responders Treat Cases of Tetanus, Malaria and Gastrointestinal Infections at St. Francis de Sales Hospital
properties.description: Tetanus, Malaria, Gastroenteritis &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Port-au-Prince Disease Entity: Malaria, tetanus, unspecified gastrointestinal infections A disaster response team from California deployed to Haiti for a seven-day stay reported that as of 1 March they were continuing to treat cases of malaria, tetanus and unspecified gastrointestinal infections at St Francis de Sales Hospital in Port-au-Prince. One team member who is also a surgeon expressed concern over the recent deaths of three individuals due to tetanus, noting the need for increased vaccinations for the Haitian population.

properties.title: Forced removal of 1200 people from Villa Manrese, Haiti
properties.description:
Not Yet Classified &mdash; Haiti<br/>Back ground:
I am a retired Firefighter doing some relief work in Haiti. I have a home in North Carolina but am living in the Dominican republic for the last few months.  After the quake I was asked by some doctor friends to lead a trip to do medical work there so on the 4th day after the quake we went in.  I am back in Haiti now preparing for the next visit of the same group. 
Story:
Last night a small camp of 1200 people were forced off the property they were camped on.  This was a camp that we had provided medical help to. This was done at night and with no warning.  1200 people moved out in darkness with no place to go many children many wounded were put out into the night. What is worse it was done by a supposed Catholic group at Villa Manrese.  The people were living behind the building on a flat spot of ground.  They were a very organized group and were in a safe place.  They had a small school there for the children.  They had food that they shared.  The directors name at Villa Manrese is Pere Andre Paul Grraud. I do not know what he knows about this but he was there in the house above the camp.  I have video of before and after this was done. I understand the need to remove the people from the property but the way they went about this must be reported.  This sort of thing has to be addressed and exposed to the world.  These people were treated like cattle and by fellow Haitians of a Catholic group. 

I am leaving Haiti Thursday for the DR but will be back in 2 weeks.  I will gladly share the video with you.

Tom Parsons 
509-3434-7816 Haiti
829-362-0013 in DR

properties.title: Puerto Rico Declares Dengue Epidemic: Implications for Haiti
properties.description: Dengue Fever &mdash; Haiti<br/>Location: Puerto Rico / Haiti Disease Entity: Dengue On Tuesday of this week, Puerto Rican Health officials declared that the island is officially experiencing a dengue epidemic. The announcement was made after the island exceeded the established dengue epidemic threshold counts for three consecutive weeks. Officials blamed unusual environmental conditions in January, including warm temperatures and rain, for the overproliferation of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which transmits dengue viruses. Areas most affected include Caguas and Arecibo on the North Coast, and Fajardo on the East Coast. We previously reported that all four dengue serotypes are circulating and considered hyperendemic in...

properties.title: Heavy Rainfall in Port-au-Prince Results in Muddy Conditions at IDP Camps
properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Operational Context Location: Port-au-Prince Last week, Port-au-Prince received heavy rain on March 4th resulting in stagnant water collection in many areas impart due to drainage ditches clogged with debris. An internally displaced persons (IDP) camp located on the Del Mar golf course in Port-au-Prince holding approximately 60,000 earthquake survivors received precipitation turning ground conditions into mud. Individuals residing in the camp describe having limited access to clean water and medical care, and no degree of sanitation infrastructure. Similarly, IDP camps located in Champ de Mars plaza near the Presidential Palace also received heavy rainfall resulting in muddy conditions...

properties.title: Three Cases of Meningitis at Saint Francois de Sales Hospital
properties.description: Meningitis &mdash; Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Saint Francois de Sales Hospital, Port-au-Prince, Haiti Disease Entity: Meningitis Multiple cases of meningitis have been reported at the Saint Francois de Sales Hospital located in Port-au-Prince within 5 days. An infectious disease physician working at the medical facility indicated two cases of meningitis have been treated; one was reported to be gram stain positive for pneumococcal meningitis, and culture results for the other two cases are pending. We will continue to monitor for new information to confirm the etiology of these cases.

properties.title: Surveillance Confusion: Measles Versus Chickenpox
properties.description: Measles, Chicken Pox &mdash; Haiti<br/>Over the years we have encountered linguistic ambiguities that tend to be misleading. One example is the Arabic language uses similar words to describe both chickenpox and smallpox. Every time this particular word appeared, analysts would become immediately concerned smallpox was once again in the world- when it was a translation and cultural nuance problem. Here in Haiti we have discovered a similar issue, where the word "rougeole (French) / sarampion (Kreyol)" is used to describe both measles and chickenpox. So this resolves the confusion where we had Haitian physicians insisting multiple cases of "measles" had shown up in our...

properties.title: Vomiting, Diarrhea, Inhalers, Antibiotics, and Responders
properties.description: Gastroenteritis &mdash; Haiti<br/>Here in our camp the newcomers have within 24 hours acquired the same vomiting +/- diarrhea seen in every other group that comes here. Prevalence remains around 30%. Several of our members are smokers- nearly all of them have bronchitis, two of which are on antibiotics and inhalers and one severe enough to require a steroid pulse and multi-day therapy. Probable COPD. All of the individuals had spent time at sea level in the city where the air quality is much worse. The below picture is what you wipe from your forehead after going downtown for a couple of hours:

properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Pétionville, Ouest, Haiti<br/>We stopped randomly at an orphanage to assess levels of pediatric diarrheal illness and other disease here in Petionville. The caretaker reported 2 out of 20 of the children had diarrhea, which is roughly in agreement with much of what we are seeing presently- the majority of sites surveyed have reported lower levels of severe diarrhea as we have had many hot and dry days now with only one rainy evening. The orphanage is located in what looks to be an area of drainage and very poor sanitation: However, the kids are happy and generally healthy by Haitian standards: Unfortunately,...

properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Haiti<br/>Updated 1124 GMT, 18 MAR 2010 Updates to the text are noted in blue. Tactical Ops. Ground-deployed in Port-au-Prince since 3 March and actively conducting assessments. Our objective has been to identify those infectious diseases that may abruptly overwhelm the ad hoc medical infrastructure or be perceived by the Haitian public to be unusual or unexpected. In other words, identification and prioritization of those infectious diseases that may become a crisis or disaster. Our operational activities include: stockpiling diarrheal disease countermeasures in preparation for potential crisis conditions expanding the informal contact network to support tactical early warning and situational awareness...

properties.title: Sanitation in Haiti's IDP Camps: A Visual Review
properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Haiti<br/>We have referenced the water and sanitation challenges in Haiti several times in this blog. Here we present visuals, walking you from the IDP camp latrine to the canals in Port-au-Prince that lead to the sea. These pictures were taken days ago. Drainage ditches such as this attempt to direct water flow away from latrines. During significant rainfall, water flows over the ditches, floods the latrines, and raw sewage instead is carried downhill. The same drainage ditch, downhill from the latrines with raw sewage and garbage. Nearby, children play in bare feet, some of whom are naked: Raw sewage, garbage,...

properties.title: REQUEST URGENT
properties.description:
Not Yet Classified &mdash; Pétionville, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Object: REQUEST FOR SHELTER - PETION VILLE


NAME OF THE PERSON IN NEED: MEME SELVANDIEU - Pr&amp;Atilde;&amp;copy;sident/ Fondateur de la Fondation Rocher du Salut d&#039;Haiti (FROCSAH)

CONTACT:  PHONE  00 (509) 3 454-4078       EMAIL meme_selvandieu@yahoo.fr

LOCALIZATION: PLACE DE SAINT PIERRE - PETION VILLE - PORT AU PRINCE (HAITI)

REQUEST: SHELTER FOR 30 PEOPLE, ASSISTANCE FOR 200 FAMILIES INCLUDING FOOD, MEDICINE AND CLOTHES, TENTS


FULL TEXT:

Good-morning,

My name is Meme Selvandieu, Pr&amp;Atilde;&amp;copy;sident/ Fondateur de la Fondation Rocher du Salut d&#039;Haiti (FROCSAH).

I found your contact searching on the Internet http://helphaitiheal.wordpress.com/shelters-camps/ (Help Haiti Heal) and https://www.cimicweb.org/cmo/haiti/Pages/default.aspx (CMO Haiti) and with the help of two Italian friends abroad (Mauro Annarumma - Doctor in the Italian Army mauro.annarumma@gmail.com and Raphael Broniatowski - Volonteer in the Italian Red Cross raphael.bro@cripadova.it)


I&#039;m writing you to request assistance for 200 families, including mine.

We are 30 people without shelter and assistance since January 12th. The other ones need food, medicines and clothes.


The friends I have contacted in Italy are trying to get in touch with the Italian Delegation of the Red Cross in Haiti through its headquarter in Rome but time is passing and we haven&#039;t received any help yet.

I understand you may be too busy to treat directly our kind of request but maybe you can tell us about new distributions of tents and  reliefs in P&amp;Atilde;&amp;copy;tion-Ville and where they are suppose to happen.

We all thank you very much for any kind of help you could give us.

We will be waiting for an answer.

properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Haiti<br/>Sent to the UN Cluster System and the broader Haiti responder community on 28 March @ 0538 GMT Greetings, The meteorological forecast for next week calls for thunderstorms beginning this Wednesday and lasting at least through the following Tuesday. We will follow the forecasts closely as this time draws near. We are all seriously concerned about an increase in diarrheal disease, specifically in children. It has already been documented that diarrheal disease is a major cause of morbidity and mortality both before the earthquake and after. properties.title: Medical Professional Reports Dehydration and Gastrointestinal Illness Primary Issue
properties.description: Gastroenteritis &mdash; Cité Soleil, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Cite Soleil, Port-au-Prince, Haiti Disease Entity: Non-specific gastrointestinal illness On March 28th, reports from a physician based in a Cite Soleil area hospital indicate dehydration and gastrointestinal illnesses continue to be the primary cause of morbidity among earthquake survivors living in temporary shelters; however, mortality due to dehydration and gastrointestinal conditions has remained low. Moreover, malaria cases are reported to be increasing as rainfall frequency and accumulation escalate. The interviewed physician noted that there is still a shortage of diagnostic equipment and health professionals available in Port-au-Prince.

properties.title: Cases of Diarrheal Disease Reported in Bellanton IDP Camp
properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Bellanton, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Bellanton, Haiti Disease Entity: Non-specified diarrheal disease A survey carried out at the Bellanton IDP camp located just due west of Savane Blonde identified cases of non-specified diarrheal disease, vomiting, febrile illness, individuals with sore eyes and women with vaginal infections suspected to be caused from exposure to contaminated water. The IDP camp at this location houses 580 families and is reported to be experiencing shortages of shelter-building material, food and clean water.

properties.description: Pneumonia &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Port-au-Prince, Haiti Disease Entity: Pneumonia A registered nurse who returned to California this week after volunteering in Haiti for a two-week period reports that the primary cause of illness and death among earthquake-affected children she evaluated was pneumonia. properties.description: Malaria &mdash; Haiti<br/>We have received this report from Croix-des-Bouquets, Departement de l'Ouest (the greater PAP area). The source of the information is of very high credibility. A couple of things to note when interpreting this information: 1. We do have the expectation of seeing an increase in malaria cases as happens this time of year routinely. 2. We expect an increase above what is typically seen due to crowded conditions in the IDP camps. 3. These findings would therefore not be considered unexpected. 4. properties.title: Contamination of the Water Supply: A Persistent Problem
properties.description: Waterborne Illness &mdash; Pétionville, Haiti<br/>This message came from an environmental health team evaluating the water supply at the Petionville IDP camp yesterday. It highlights a serious challenging in maintaining a protected water supply to the public: The tests taken at the source of the water (ie the water bladders) passed. The water at the camp household level failed (testing positive for fecal coliform when taken from the drinking glass, after transported to the shelter and manipulated). This would not be a surprise in any camp in Haiti at the moment, but underscores the fact that the handling of water post delivery (the containers used...

properties.description: Not Yet Classified &mdash; Haiti<br/>WFP has released its latest assessment of the food security situation in Haiti, indicating a deteriorating situation. The concerns from a biosurveillance perspective relate to The potential for a shift in demand for protein sources. While the Ministry of Agriculture and USSOUTHCOM took the initiative to vaccinate livestock for anthrax, there are over 2 million estimated goats this vaccination campaign did not cover. properties.title: Suicide Surveillance

Here we report suicides: [Carrefour] Report by medical personnel of 6 attempted suicides by chlorine ingestion over the past couple of weeks. [Petionville] Attempted suicide by Haitian nurse. These reports likely are the tip of the iceberg and represent an indicator for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

properties.title: Physician at Port-au-Prince General Hospital Reports Concern Over Tuberculosis
properties.description: Tuberculosis &mdash; Port-au-Prince General Hospital <br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Port-au-Prince, Haiti Disease Entity: Tuberculosis A physician from the United States volunteering at Port-au-Prince General Hospital reports concern over tuberculosis activity among internally displaced persons treated at the medical facility. The physician noted that it is commonplace for infected individuals to wait until their condition is severe before obtaining medical care. When tuberculosis cases delay seeking medical care there is an increased risk of transmission to close contacts. A recent publication in the New England Journal of...

properties.title: American Red Cross Reports Seeing an Increase in Malaria

So it's a lot to reach. Now, one other thing that the American Red Cross is doing is we're doing a lot of education around malaria. Unfortunately, we are seeing an increase in malaria in Haiti, and what we're distributing, obviously, with all of our relief supplies are mosquito nets. And we're encouraging people, teaching them how to put the nets on and to use them. And these are the kinds of disease prevention measures that we're taking.

properties.title: Escalating Tensions in Port-au-Prince
properties.description: Conflict &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Ouest, Haiti<br/>A new report has identified growing tension in Cite Soleil, where gangs are reportedly arming themselves over perceived discrepancies between international donations and visible benefit to the poorest communities in the city. One of the HEAS community members was forced to cancel operations in Cite Soleil due to these escalating tensions. The social order-health security nexus risk was highlighted multiple times by HEAS beginning on 11 FEB. We assess an uncontrolled infectious disease crisis involving diarrheal disease, malaria, or pandemic H1N1 may further exacerbate the security situation.

properties.description: Diphtheria &mdash; Port-au-Prince General Hospital <br/>One of the HEAS partners has reported a confirmed case of diphtheria who is intubated at PAP General Hospital. After hours of searching, the sole source of immunoglobin for the patient was found at PROMESS. Nearly all of the major hospitals were queried, major NGOs, multiple clinics and the Haitian Ministry of Health- no one was able to tell the responding medical team where the immunoglobulin was located. properties.description: Malaria &mdash; Petit Goâve, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Petit Goave, Haiti Disease Entity: Malaria A member of the International Federation of Red Cross Red Crescent working in Petit Goâve reports that malaria is now the primary health issue among earthquake survivors, noting that approximately 30 percent of patients being treated are diagnosed with malaria. properties.description:
Diphtheria &mdash; Haiti<br/> Last updated May 9, 2010 4:12 p.m. PT 
 Health official: No sign of Haiti diphtheria spike 
 THE ASSOCIATED PRESS 
 PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- A 15-year-old boy has died of diphtheria in Haiti, but there is no evidence the bacterial disease is spreading in the earthquake-ravaged country, U.N. health officials said Sunday. 
The boy, a survivor of the Jan. 12 earthquake, died last week despite receiving antitoxin treatments, said Anshu Banerjee, an official with the World Health Organization.

properties.title: WHO Officials Do Not Find Evidence of Diphtheria Spread
properties.description: Diphtheria &mdash; Haiti<br/>The formal disease surveillance system, the IDP Surveillance System (IDPSS), remains down and not producing reports. World Health Organization officials have indicated they see no evidence of diphtheria transmission, however confidence in that observation should be challenged. There remains clear limitations to infectious disease surveillance, difficulty in conducting investigations in the multitude of IDP camps, inability to fully validate vaccination status, questionable vaccination coverage, and limited operational coupling between infectious disease event warning and rapid response. The question remains how the child became exposed to diphtheria in the first place, and why there was such a time delay in locating...

The logical question could be asked about what the status of the Ministry of Health will be as well as its operations related to infectious disease surveillance and response. properties.title: CLARIFICATION: Diphtheria in Haiti
properties.description: Diphtheria &mdash; Cité Soleil, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Yesterday's report contained mention of an HEAS partner who reported a suspected outbreak of diphtheria at the same location, Cite Soleil as mentioned by the Unicef representative to the press in Geneva. We have come to understand that particular report does not refer to Cite Soleil but rather "Camp Canaan" adjacent to Camp Corail, intersection of Highway One and Nine, 12 miles north of PAP. This should be considered an unconfirmed report. Authorities have been appraised of this discrepancy.

properties.title: Continued Miscommunication Between Public Health and Medical Responders in Haiti
properties.description: Diphtheria &mdash; Haiti<br/>We have had a request for information from one of the HEAS partners regarding the status of new identification of diphtheria cases. They are making decisions to scale back diphtheria vaccinations due to supply / cost considerations and were wondering if anyone had information to suggest diphtheria activity remains "live". The IDPSS continues to exclude reporting of diphtheria, despite Unicef's international declaration of an activated emergency vaccination campaign. This reflects ongoing disconnect between formal syndromic surveillance and operational reality. Minimal communication between public health and those who are providing care to the Haitians continues to impair proper, coordinated response.

properties.title: UPDATE: Security Situation in Haiti
properties.description: Conflict &mdash; Haiti<br/>The MINUSTAH JOTC reported on May 25th (this is the formal report stemming from the Flash Report we posted two days ago) that, The overall security situation in Haiti has become volatile, with sporadic anti-government demonstrations by the political opposition. A recent rekindling of criminal violence has also provoked renewed concerns. On 24 May, five demonstrations were reported. In the first, in Gonaïves, a demonstration organized by teachers from ‘l’Association des Educateurs de Dessalines’ demanded the recognition of the education system in Marchand Dessalines locality by the Government. A second, in Pétion-Ville, brought together around 100 persons calling on government...

properties.description: Environmental &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Haiti<br/>Live report from an HEAS partner on the ground in Haiti: Flash flooding across PAP to Delmas causing heavy traffic congestion, several roads currently un-passable, various EMS [Emergency Medical Service] routes blocked. Rerouting through back roads south of airport, security of back roads in area questionable.

properties.title: Two Outbreaks of Tuberculosis in Florida Triggers Public Outcry Against Haitian Immigration
properties.description: Tuberculosis &mdash; Florida<br/>Media report in Palm Beach County, Florida that two separate elementary schools have outbreaks of tuberculosis. Parents at Seminole Ridge High School in Loxahatchee and Orchard View Elementary in Delray Beach have blamed recent immigrant Haitian students for the outbreaks. This is an example of public outcry leveled at public health in the context of unexpected or non-routine pediatric infectious disease threats. Similar behavior was observed in many countries, including the United States, during the emergence of pandemic H1N1 in elementary schools. properties.title: Typhoid Outbreak Reported in Camp Acra-Delmas, PAP
properties.description: Typhoid &mdash; Haiti<br/>A total of 82 suspected, 31 of which were confirmed, typhoid cases were reported by the American Refugee Committee in Camp Acra from June 22 to 25. Fifty-two of the suspected cases were above the age of 5 years old. The outbreak appears to be concluding now, however transmission in areas outside of the camp remains uncertain. This is not an unexpected finding, as typhoid is endemic in Haiti. This event is representative of an IDIS Category 1 at this point.

properties.title: Caribbean thousand infection of dengue fever outbreak
properties.description: Dengue Fever &mdash; Haiti<br/>加勒比海沿岸诸国眼下遭遇登革热疫情,数十人死亡,数以千计民众确诊感染这种由蚊虫叮咬传染的地区性急性传染病。　多米尼加、波多黎各、特立尼达和多巴哥等地卫生部门紧急行动,呼吁民众大力灭蚊。 　美联社18日援引多米尼加公共卫生部长包蒂斯塔·罗哈斯·戈麦斯的话报道,超过5000人确诊罹患登革热。截至18日,多米尼加已有至少27名患者死亡。 　 波多黎各疾病控制和预防中心部门主管凯·托马舍克说,截至7月中旬,至少5人死于这种传染病;医疗机构报告收治大约6300个疑似病例。 　泛美卫生组织公布的最新统计显示,截至6月上旬,加勒比海地区报告病例数超过1.67万。 　各国卫生部门官员说,由于今年天气暖和、提前进入雨季,蚊虫数量激增,导致经由蚊虫叮咬传染的登革热疫情暴发。 (本文来源:京华时报。

Cholera — Grande Anse, Sud-Est, Haiti UN: Haiti's cholera outbreak is easing but some rural areas see spike in deaths 
–
 3 hours ago 
GENEVA — Haiti's cholera outbreak appears to be diminishing nationwide but the death rate in rural areas remains alarmingly high, the United Nations said Friday. 
The mixed picture comes from Haitian government figures citing 231,070 reported cases and 4,549 deaths since the epidemic began in October.
